document.ModsDocTitle: A new species of the leafhopper genus Maiestas Distant from Australia (Hemiptera, Cicadellidae, Deltocephalinae, Deltocephalini)
document.docAuthor: Duan, Yani, Dietrich, Christopher H. & Zhang, Yalin
document.docTitle: Maiestas irwini Duan, Dietrich & Zhang, 2017, sp. n.
document.masterDocTitle: A new species of the leafhopper genus Maiestas Distant from Australia (Hemiptera, Cicadellidae, Deltocephalinae, Deltocephalini)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new species of the leafhopper genus Maiestas Distant from Australia (Hemiptera, Cicadellidae, Deltocephalinae, Deltocephalini)

caption.paragraph: Figure 1. Maiestas irwini sp. n. A, B habitus, dorsal view C habitus, lateral view D face.

Figure 2. Maiestas irwini sp. n. A male pygofer lobe, lateral view B, C male pygofer and segments X-XI , dorsal view D valve, subgenital plates and styles, ventral view E style, dorsal view F, G connective and aedeagus, dorsal and lateral view, respectively.

subSubSection.paragraph: Holotype: 1 male, 4km up Black Mountain Road, via Kuranda, 14.ix.-12.x.1982, malaise trap (QM, T234944, ex QDPI). Paratypes: 1 male, same data as holotype (QDPI); 2 males, same data as previous but 14. ix- 12.x.1982, G. Simpson (QDPI); 1 male, 1 female, same data as holotype but 12-26.x.1982 (QDPI); 3 males, 3 females, Moggill State Forest, 26 km W Brisbane, Queensland, 17.x.1983, M. E. Irwin, malaise trap in gully in eucalyptus (INHS); 1 male, Mount Baldy Rd via Atherton, N Queensland, vi.1981, J. D. Brown, malaise trap (QDPI); 1 male, Tully Falls Rd, 10.iii.1956, J. L. Gressitt, light trap (BPB).

The male genitalia of this species are similar to those of Maiestas scriptus (Distant), from India (Webb & Viraktamath, 2009, Fig. 33) with a short and broad subgenital plate with lateral margin well rounded (Fig. 2D), style apophysis relatively long and straight (Fig. 2E), and aedeagal shaft short (Fig. 2 F-G ), but Maiestas irwini differs in color pattern, the more strongly produced head (Fig. 1 A-B ), and less acute aedeagal apex in dorsal view (Fig. 2F). The new species differs from other Australian species (see Fletcher, 2016) in coloration and genital morphology.
This species is named for M. E. Irwin who collected much of the type series.
